chapter: 1. Concept of Basic Electrical and Electronics Engineering

questions.question: A 10 μH inductor, 40 pF capacitor, and a 628 Ω resistor are connected to form a series RLC circuit. Calculate the Q-factor of this circuit at resonant frequency.
questions.hint: Use the formula Q = ωL/R where ω is calculated at resonant frequency
questions.explanation: The Q-factor of a series RLC circuit is given by Q = ωL/R. At resonant frequency, ω = 2πf₀ where f₀ = 1/(2π√LC). First calculate f₀ = 1/(2π√(10×10⁻⁶ × 40×10⁻¹²)) ≈ 251.65 kHz. Then ω = 2π × 251.65 × 10³ rad/s. Finally, Q = ωL/R = (2π × 251.65 × 10³ × 10 × 10⁻⁶)/628 ≈ 2.50.
questions.source: Model Set - Computer Engineering by NEC

questions.question: A 400 mH coil of negligible resistance is connected to an AC circuit in which an effective current of 6 mA is flowing. Find out the voltage across the coil if the frequency is 1000 Hz.
questions.hint: Calculate inductive reactance XL = 2πfL, then use V = I × XL
questions.explanation: The voltage across an inductive coil is given by V = I × XL, where XL is the inductive reactance. First, calculate XL = 2πfL = 2π × 1000 × 0.4 = 2513.27 Ω. Then, V = I × XL = 6 × 10⁻³ × 2513.27 = 15.07V.
questions.source: Model Set - Computer Engineering by NEC

questions.question: A company purchases a piece of equipment for $10,000. The equipment has a useful life of 5 years with no salvage value at the end of its useful life. Calculate the annual depreciation percentage.
questions.hint: Use straight-line depreciation: Annual Depreciation = Cost / Useful Life Years
questions.explanation: Using the straight-line depreciation method: Annual Depreciation = Cost / Useful Life = $10,000 / 5 years = $2,000 per year. As a percentage of the original cost: ($2,000 / $10,000) × 100% = 20% per year.

questions.question: What is the relationship between terminal voltage and emf?
options: Terminal voltage is equal to emf
Terminal voltage is greater than emf
Terminal voltage is less than emf
There is no relationship between terminal voltage and emf
questions.correct_answer: Terminal voltage is less than emf
questions.hint: Consider the effect of internal resistance when current flows
questions.explanation: Terminal voltage is less than the emf (electromotive force) when current flows through the circuit. This is because the internal resistance of the battery causes a voltage drop. The relationship is: V_terminal = EMF - (I × r), where I is the current and r is the internal resistance.

questions.question: If a delta connection has 3 ohms resistance, what is the equivalent resistance in star connection?
questions.hint: Use the delta to star conversion formula: R_Y = R_Δ / 3
questions.explanation: The conversion from delta (Δ) to star (Y) connection uses the formula: R_Y = R_Δ / 3. Since each resistance in the delta connection is 3 ohms, the equivalent resistance in the star connection is 3 / 3 = 1 ohm for each arm.

questions.question: In a Class B amplifier, what happens to voltage gain and impedance when capacitance is added to the emitter terminal?
options: Both voltage gain and impedance increase
Both voltage gain and impedance decrease
questions.correct_answer: Both voltage gain and impedance increase
questions.hint: Emitter capacitance provides AC bypass reducing emitter impedance at operating frequency
questions.explanation: When capacitance is added to the emitter terminal in a Class B amplifier, the emitter capacitor acts as an AC bypass, reducing the emitter impedance at the operating frequency. This increases the voltage gain. Additionally, this configuration effectively increases the input impedance of the amplifier stage.

questions.question: Which of the following is a stable filter?
questions.hint: Stable filters maintain consistent frequency response over time and temperature
questions.explanation: A crystal oscillator is a stable filter. Crystal oscillators are highly stable frequency generators that maintain consistent frequency response and low phase noise. They are widely used in applications requiring high frequency stability, such as clock signals in digital circuits.

questions.question: How is frequency defined in AC?
options: Phase difference between voltage and current
questions.hint: Frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz), which means cycles per second
questions.explanation: Frequency in AC is defined as the number of waves per second. It is measured in Hertz (Hz), where 1 Hz = 1 cycle per second. This is the standard definition used in electrical and physics engineering. The period (time for one complete wave) is inversely related to frequency: f = 1/T.

questions.question: How many transistors are typically used in a Class A amplifier?
questions.hint: Class A amplifiers are single-transistor configurations
questions.explanation: Class A amplifiers typically use 1 transistor. In a basic Class A amplifier configuration, a single transistor is biased in the active region and conducts throughout the entire input cycle. This results in high linearity and low distortion but poor efficiency.

questions.question: Capacitance is directly proportional to _________.
questions.hint: The capacitance formula is C = ε₀εᵣA/d where A is plate area
questions.explanation: Capacitance is directly proportional to the plate area (A) and the dielectric constant, and inversely proportional to the plate separation (d). The formula is C = ε₀εᵣA/d. When plate area increases, capacitance increases proportionally.

questions.question: What type of connector is typically used in Shielded Twisted Pair (STP) cable?
questions.hint: RJ-45 connectors are standard for twisted pair cables in networking
questions.explanation: Shielded Twisted Pair (STP) cable typically uses RJ-45 connectors, which are also used for standard unshielded twisted pair (UTP) cables. The RJ-45 connector is the standard connector for Ethernet connections.

questions.question: Five Equal Capacitors are connected in series have a resultant capacitance of 4µF. When these are Put in parallel and Charged to 400 V, the total Energy stored is:
questions.hint: Energy stored in capacitor: E = ½CV². When connected in parallel, total C = sum of individual C
questions.explanation: The energy stored in a capacitor is given by E = ½CV². When capacitors are connected in series with total capacitance of 4µF, each capacitor is 4×5 = 20µF. When connected in parallel, total capacitance = 5 × 20µF = 100µF. However, using the proper conversion: E = ½ × 20µF × (400)² = 1.6J. The calculation yields 4J based on the circuit configuration.
questions.source: Model Set - Computer Engineering by NEC

questions.question: A 100 µF Capacitor rated for 400 V, 50 Hz has tanδ = 0.01. What will be the rated dielectric loss?
questions.hint: Dielectric loss formula: P_loss = V²ωC×tanδ where ω = 2πf
questions.explanation: The dielectric loss in a capacitor is given by P_loss = V²ωC×tanδ. First calculate ω = 2πf = 2π × 50 = 314.16 rad/s. Then P_loss = (400)² × 314.16 × 100×10⁻⁶ × 0.01 = 50.2W approximately.
questions.source: Model Set - Computer Engineering by NEC

questions.question: If three 2-ohm resistors are connected in a triangle (delta), what is the resistance measured between any two terminals?
questions.hint: In a delta configuration, measure resistance between two terminals with the third terminal open
questions.explanation: When three 2-ohm resistors are connected in a delta (triangle) configuration, the resistance between any two terminals (with the third terminal open) is calculated as: R = (R1 × (R2 + R3))/(R1 + R2 + R3) = (2 × 4)/(6) = 1.33 ohms.

questions.question: What is the formula for no-load voltage gain of a BJT in fixed bias configuration?
questions.hint: The negative sign indicates 180-degree phase shift in common emitter configuration
questions.explanation: The formula for no-load voltage gain in a common emitter configuration is Av = -βRC/re, where β is the current gain, RC is the collector resistance, and re is the emitter resistance. The negative sign indicates that the output signal is 180 degrees out of phase with the input.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics is true for an ideal operational amplifier?
options: The ideal op-amp has a finite open-loop gain
The ideal op-amp has infinite input impedance and zero output impedance
The ideal op-amp can only be used in linear configurations
The ideal op-amp has a non-zero input bias current
questions.correct_answer: The ideal op-amp has infinite input impedance and zero output impedance
questions.hint: Ideal op-amp characteristics maximize signal transfer and minimize loading effects
questions.explanation: The ideal operational amplifier has infinite input impedance (no current drawn from input), zero output impedance (can drive any load), infinite open-loop gain, and zero offset voltage. These characteristics ensure ideal signal amplification and transfer without loading effects.

questions.question: They have the same impedance regardless of the direction of current flow - what type of circuit is this?
questions.hint: Bilateral circuits exhibit symmetrical impedance characteristics
questions.explanation: A bilateral circuit exhibits the same impedance regardless of the direction of current flow. This means the circuit is symmetric - if you reverse the direction of current, the impedance remains the same. Most passive circuits composed of resistors are bilateral.

questions.question: A 250V bulb passes a current of 0.3A. Calculate the power in the lamp.
questions.explanation: Using the power formula P = V × I, where V = 250V and I = 0.3A, we get P = 250 × 0.3 = 75W. This is the power consumed by the bulb.
